To beauteous, dear, delightful, witching woman,</br>The noblest bards have poured their deathless lays</br>And in the muse's train, it were uncommon,</br>To find a minstrel silent in her praise.</br>In reverence for the sex, I yield to no man;</br>To them, my heart its silent homage pays;</br>And still I wonder, as I think about them,</br>How dismal were our fate, if doomed to live without them.

There is so much in women to admire,</br>In youth so kind, in age so wise and solemn;</br>That would Apollo but impart the fire,</br>I'd sing their virtues in a quarto volume.</br>But faint the warblings of my rustic lyre,</br>And niggard fate forbids to raise a column;</br>Then humbly bowing to my fortune stern,</br>I, like a Scotsman true, will heap a little cairn.

Of modern monuments to woman's fame,</br>Byron's are built of marble, dark and strong;</br>And on the pedestal is many a name</br>His hand has rescued from oblivion's throng.</br>Moore's is a gilded altar, where a flame</br>Breathes luscious fragrance, softly borne along;</br>On this we gaze — admire its beauteous polish;</br>That ruder form, we own, time only can demolish,

But both, ungrateful to their native land,</br>Of foreign beauties have enraptured sung;</br>Their forms have sculptured with unwearied hand,</br>And round the statutes loveliest drapery hung:</br>Forgot, the graces of Green Erin's strand,</br>And Caledonia's daughters fair and young:</br>To Lalla Rookh, Moore's strings his softest lyre,</br>And infidels alone can Byron's muse inspire.

Though Scotia cannot boast her myrtle vales,</br>Yet waving birch, and sweetly scented thorn,</br>Breathe gentle fragrance to the twilight gales,</br>And waft their odours on the breeze of morn:</br>Around, rich Commerce spreads her whitening sails,</br>Mid golden harvests her gay fields adorn;</br>Her rivers roll, soft glide her crystal rills,</br>And o'er her flowery glens, high tower her heath-clad hills.

Her woodlands wave with buds and bushes green,</br>Where many a warbler plumes his wanton wing,</br>When dewy morning sheds her smile serene,</br>Their song of love makes rocks and vallies ring.</br>In sun-bright summer, breathes the scented bean,</br>And cowslips deck the mossy banks of spring,</br>Her lowing herds in every vale abound,</br>And flocks, with fleeces white, bleat on the hills around.

But Scotia, still of nobler wealth possess'd,</br>Can boast her hardy independent swains;</br>And fairer, lovelier sweets, are hers confess'd,</br>Than waving woods, green fields, and flowery plains.</br>The modest virgin's blush, and swelling breast,</br>Where love in secret sits, to forge his chains,</br>'Midst every charm, and winning nameless grace,</br>That beauty deigns to shed on woman's angel face!

This brings me to the point from whence I started,</br>From which, I own, I've made sad aberration,</br>But every reader, if he's patriot-hearted,</br>I'm sure will smile, and pardon the digression.</br>Besides, when from my subject I departed,</br>It was not easy to resist temptation,</br>For dearly as I value woman's charms,</br>'Tis Caledonia's fair that all my bosom warm.

Fair country-women, is it not a shame,</br>For Byron's muse your beauties to neglect,</br>To dwell with rapture on a stranger's name,</br>And hang his pearls about a Tartar's neck</br>However fair?  I think he's much to blame;</br>Your virtues claimed a little more respect;</br>And they should echo over land and sea,</br>If I like him could sing — if he could love like me.

Methinks, I see your cheek with anger flush,</br>And scorn the praise his Lordship could bestow;</br>The Laureate of Don Juan! — do not blush—</br>No Scotian fair e'er read the book I know!—</br>Though you have heard the public talk — but hush!</br>I hail and laud that bashful modest glow;</br>Cheer up, loved fair!  nor fear oblivion's lake,</br>Yet better sink forgot, than float in Julia's wake.

Shame to the bard, who prostitutes his skill</br>To flout the sex, in vile lampoons satiric;</br>For me, I've every want, except the will</br>To sing your praise, in sonnet, ode, and lyric!</br>Dull as I am, more softly glides my quill,</br>Whene'er employed, to write your panegyric:</br>Even now, inspired, so warm my bosom glows,</br>I feel my pen unfit for writing sober prose!

But though I long to shine in epic glory,</br>At first, I must not soar too near the sun;</br>For trust me, I should be exceeding sorry</br>To fall, my flight so short, and just begun.</br>Well, let me try a short and simple story;</br>Perchance the muse may make it smoothly run;</br>Yet I have fears — this stanza is so bad,</br>It is not poetry, but measured prose run mad!

My scene's in Forfar, fam'd the country round,</br>For leather brogues, and philosophic lore;</br>For Osnaburgs, peat-reek, and law profound;</br>A lake, more famous far in days of yore;</br>Its muddy waters many a witch had drowned;</br>The muse might tell of twenty wonders more;</br>Such as its mosses, marl, and modern steeple,</br>That ornaments the kirk as piety the people.

But let them pass — I must my theme pursue;</br>Yet gentle readers, ere we further go,</br>My tale is old, although the version's new;</br>You must look back, some sixty years, or so;</br>But still, perhaps, it may be strange to you,</br>Although your face does disappointment shew;</br>In fond anticipation, you expected</br>To hear of Radicals and lordly self-elected!

But borough politics have long been stale,</br>Beyond the boundaries of the corporation;</br>They'll do for deacons, guzzling home-brew'd ale,</br>Or magistrates, for evening recreation:</br>One party finds them like a thrice-told tale;</br>The other hates to hear their botheration!</br>Between them, if you please, we'll leave the strife;</br>Far better hear my tale — 'tis of domestic life.

Tom Hood was young — a blacksmith to his trade,</br>His smithy stood just midway down the Spout;</br>The noise his hammers in the morning made,</br>Roused young and old from rest, all round about;</br>For Thomas was a thrifty thriving blade;</br>Whoever called, the blacksmith ne'er was out:</br>And though the lasses bloom'd, like roses, round him,</br>Nor Love, with subtle dart, nor Beauty's charms could wound him.

Tom had a tongue that never tir'd of talking,</br>His eloquence in native fervour glowed;</br>His stature tall, he seem'd a May-pole stalking;</br>A Hercules — earth trembled as he trod;</br>But still, he was not quite the thing for walking;</br>For on the street his gait was somewhat odd;</br>The cause was one, would neither cure nor smother,</br>One limb, though not a lath, was shorter than its brother.

Kate Gow was fair, a gaudy flaunting flower,</br>Just in the noon of youth and beauty's pride;</br>And saw delighted, at the twilight hour,</br>The Beaux, by dozens, crowding at her side,</br>Who flatter'd, fawn'd, and own'd her beauty's power,</br>And made her time on rosy pinions glide;</br>Then left the fair one, fancied conquests dreaming;</br>Now musing on the past — now future projects scheming.

For Kate was not the lily of the vale,</br>That bends its head beneath the dews of morn;</br>Neither was she the modest primrose pale,</br>That meekly blooms beneath the sheltering thorn:</br>She was a garden flower, that fear'd the gale,</br>And long'd some gentle bosom to adorn; </br>She could not stoop — would ne'er degrade her charms,</br>To hide her virgin blushes in a rustic's arms.

For she a lady's maid some years had been,</br>And knew the fashions of a drawing-room;</br>Of modish manners, much had learned and seen,</br>And many an art for heightening beauty's bloom;</br>Knew how to dress, and where to place each pin,</br>Amidst the labours of the silken loom;</br>What colour best became her beauteous face,</br>And all that could improve each native virgin grace.

And nature had on Kate (benignly kind)</br>Bestowed a face beyond most others fair;</br>If features were an index to the mind,</br>Of wit and spirit she had ample share;</br>Her slender neck and sparkling eye combined</br>To give the maid a most enchanting air;</br>Her smile so gentle, seemed to say, "Come, sip</br>Young Love's celestial nectar from my ruby lip!"

Had niggard Fortune been but as propitious,</br>The maid might then had husbands, pick and clause;</br>She had gallants, who thought it most delicious,</br>When she would smile, their evenings to amuse;</br>But they were such as deemed it injudicious</br>To run their necks into the marriage noose:</br>True, she had been to Hymen's fane invited,</br>But it was still by those her pride or prudence slighted.

Two hungry lawyers, lacking food and fees,</br>With faces sallow, as a parchment skin,</br>Were both nonsuited in their amorous pleas;</br>Next came a splay-foot weaver, lank and thin;</br>A son of Crispin sought the fair to please,</br>A shoe-brush bristling on his greasy chin;</br>A London tailor hoped her mind to measure;</br>The trio was dismissed — such was the lady's pleasure.

Hope, that had once a burning meteor blazed,</br>Now dwindled to a dimly twinkling star,</br>Which fainter grew as Catherine fondly gazed,</br>And clouds would sometimes all her vision mar:</br>And when her languid eye the maiden raised,</br>She saw it glimmering in the welkin far,</br>Its distance greater each revolving night,</br>And sick was she at heart to view its waning light.

Kate to religion paid the reverence due;</br>Tom Hood was seated near her every Sunday;</br>Her face, set fairly in the blacksmith's view,</br>Made dreadful havock in his heart, on Monday!  </br>In vain he tried his passion to subdue,—</br>Love lent him courage, and the lad went one day—</br>Where think you?  To the barber to be trimmed,</br>His black and bushy beard with culm and smoke begrimmed.

Removed his weekly crop of bristling hair,</br>And in his Sunday clothing neatly dress'd,</br>He sat till twilight curtained o'er the air,</br>Love, like his bellows, heaving in his breast;</br>Then limping, hastened to the beauteous fair,</br>And in her ear his ardent love express'd:</br>She meant to smile; but happening to look down,</br>Glanced on his crooked foot, and changed it to a frown.

Kate feigned resentment, which she did not feel;</br>But prudently resolved his suit to parry;</br>And calmly answered thus the man of steel,</br>"No Sir — I think — I'm sure — I'll never marry;</br>But even if I've a match in Fortune's wheel,</br>I'm not in haste — and rather chuse to tarry</br>Than wed with you — a blacksmith — lame beside!</br>The world would think me rash and fain to be a bride!"

Tom Hood had mother-wit, and common sense,</br>And felt it not his interest nor good breeding</br>To let a lady's language give offence,</br>Though wounded pride was in his bosom bleeding;</br>But prudence whispered, "Send your anger hence,</br>And shew your wit, since you're a man of reading;"</br>For Tooke's Pantheon taught the lad mythology,</br>And memory brought to mind a passing fair apology.

He smiled, and said, "Dear Kate!  I'm sure you know</br>The tale of Venus, Queen of Love and Beauty;</br>Her husband, Vulcan, ne'er was deemed a beau;</br>Like me — a blacksmith, cripple, grim, and sooty!</br>Now you are Venus, Queen of Love below,</br>And I, your Vulcan, pledge my love and duty;</br>And since a kindred goddess sets example,</br>You cannot, charming Kate, on such a pattern trample!"

Tom's rhet'ric was so flattering to her pride,</br>That though she tried, she could not look unkind;</br>He went and came; she faintly still denied,—</br>Then craved for time, till she made up her mind—</br>At last, as ladies do, she blushed and sighed,</br>With silent meekness, to her fate resigned:</br>He got a legal charter to her charms,</br>And blooming Venus lay in Vulcan's brawny arms!

Tradition tells us, that their honey-moon</br>Was sweet and fragrant as the blooming heather;</br>They seem'd a couple, in an air-balloon,</br>That lightly soared above the world together;</br>Love shed around them all his summer noon,</br>His sun-bright skies, and warm delightful weather;</br>How long it lasted, we can but conjecture;</br>Folks cannot always sup on blushes, smiles, and nectar.

When conquering love his youthful victim captures,</br>His tickling shafts just titillate the frame,</br>The subtle poison kindles into raptures,</br>And fancy deems they still for ever flame;</br>But wedlock's history has its different chapters,</br>And one would tire to find them all the same;</br>The sun resplendent we more highly prize,</br>When thunder-clouds and storms have darkened o'er the skies.

The wisdom by our great-grandfathers earned,</br>Tom's mother taught, and he had ne'er forgot;</br>For they were laws which half an eye discerned</br>Such as "'Tis industry that boils the pot;"</br>"Bad lessons grow to habits when they're learned;"</br>"A penny saved is just a penny got."</br>These maxims had too much of Tom's regard,</br>They formed the constant rule by which his life was squared.

At early morn, (his Kate in slumbers drowned,)</br>Up Tom would rise — his daily toil begin;</br>The bellows heave with deep and hollow sound,</br>And strike the anvil with such thundering din</br>As waked the fair one from her sleep profound,</br>Whene'er he deemed it time to rise and spin;</br>And would perhaps some pleasing dream destroy,</br>Some visionary bliss, which she could ne'er enjoy.

The happiest minds will sometimes languor feel,</br>The brightest eye be dimmed in slumbers deep;</br>While Tom was hammering at the stubborn steel,</br>With Kate the leaden hours would slowly creep;</br>The ceaseless humming of her drowsy wheel</br>Would almost lull the lovely fair asleep,</br>For having led a talking, lightsome life,</br>The change was great indeed, — a dull domestic wife!

To cheat the lingering hours, that seemed so heavy,</br>Kate sought for comfort in a cup of tea;</br>With half a score of gossips at her levee,</br>When o'er their Congo, Hyson, or Bohea,</br>Such tittle-tattle would inspire the bevy </br>That all was laughter, frolic, mirth, and glee,</br>And sometimes, when the dames were wondrous frisky,</br>They parted o'er a glass of good Glenlivet whisky.

Were I inclined my subject to prolong,</br>The muse could sing of much that makes us merry;</br>The virtues of that sedative souchong,</br>And cheering influence of the Mocha berry,</br>With frothy chocolate eke out the song,</br>And cocoa too — but I in kindness spare ye;</br>Although, perhaps, the lay might still delight ye,</br>Were I to add a verse in praise of aqua vitae.

I'm well aware, that courtly Roman Flaccus</br>Could smack his lips, and sing the joys of wine;</br>The Greek, Anacreon, worshipped jolly Bacchus,</br>And round his brows the ivy loved to twine;</br>And we have bards, who boast, and boldly crack, as</br>Good whisky were a beverage most divine:</br>For me, I deem it man-destroying liquor—</br>Why did the dram-glass e'er supplant the brown-ale bicker?

So thought Tom Hood; and reader, so think I;</br>But then, the blacksmith thought the same of tea,</br>The clattering cups still made his bosom sigh;</br>And there with him, I flatly disagree;</br>It cheers the brain, lights up the drowsy eye,</br>I'm sure the ladies will accord with me!</br>Come muse, proceed — we never can be wrong,</br>If maids, and wives, and widows, all approve the song.

Tom's heart was grieved, to see his darling Kate</br>Twice every day sip the insipid trash;</br>Besides, it did the blacksmith's bosom grate</br>To find it made such inroads on the cash;</br>But his dislike arose to downright hate,</br>When six or eight sat down to sip and clash,</br>And though good manners forced him to be civil,</br>A gadding, wanton crew!  he wished them at the d—l!

His tortured mind in cogitation wandered,</br>With grief he saw the coterie increasing;</br>While o'er their cups he heard his neighbours slandered—</br>And then the afternoon oft spent in dressing—</br>Thus, time and money both were sadly squandered,</br>A tradesman's house could not afford such messing;</br>But Kate was docile, and would list to reason,</br>If it were gently told, and at a proper season.

Night seemed the time.  Tom introduced the strain,</br>With long and laboured praises of frugality,</br>And though he wished his house should still retain,</br>And practise all the rites of hospitality,</br>Yet it were foolish, and far worse than vain,</br>For tradesmen's wives to follow folks of quality.</br>"I loathe," said he, "your idling gossips' chatter!</br>And beg, I may not hear so many tea-cups clatter."

Tom's pedantry 'bout him of Lemnos isle,</br>In Catherine's breast had anxious itching bred;</br>For though she heard him with approving smile,</br>She ne'er of Vulcan and his Venus read; </br>But nought her chace of knowledge could beguile,</br>With such a wondrous history in her head;</br>By perseverance, and some private friends,</br>Kate got the tale in full, prompt at her finger ends.

Tom clos'd his counsel with a kiss most kind;</br>"'Tis thus," thought Kate, "you would your wife cajole!</br>Though he must lightly prize a woman's mind,</br>Who would her simple pleasures thus control;</br>But, stingy Vulcan, you may come to find,</br>Your Venus has an independent soul;</br>Yes smile, or frown, kiss, counsel, or make speeches,</br>My resolution's formed, that I shall wear the breeches!"

Kate, thus resolved to stand upon her mettle,</br>Next week invites her cronies half a score,</br>When brightly burnished was the copper kettle,</br>And nicely sanded the snug parlour floor:</br>"To-night," thinks she, "the dubious point shall settle,</br>My reign confirm — the rights of wives restore; </br>If spouse should gloom, and look a little sulky,</br>Yet sure, the Queen of Love can manage honest Vulky."

It was a warm and sultry afternoon,</br>The smith, half naked, o'er his furnace broiling;</br>(For it was in the latter end of June,)</br>And he was thirsty, o'er the anvil toiling;</br>And from his temples sweat was pouring down,</br>As if his marrow and his brains were oiling;</br>When past the door he saw the gossips flocking,</br>He made the bellows groan, the case was so provoking.

Who has not seen new ale in bottle pent,</br>While in the process of brisk fermentation?</br>It hisses, fumes, and struggles for a vent,</br>In furious, dire, internal perturbation.</br>The foaming liquor, still on freedom bent,</br>No longer can control its agitation,</br>Bounce goes the cork!  or crash the bottle flies,</br>While froth and shivered glass salute the gazer's eyes.

So felt Tom Hood, in that eventful hour</br>Of rank rebellion to his sovereign will;</br>Such stern defiance of a husband's power,</br>Did all his soul with deeds of vengeance fill.</br>He stamped, and swore, "Yes, Madam!  you shall cower,</br>And find, with shame, that I'll be master still."</br>Such was his wrath — such strength in every stroke,</br>That every blow he dealt a hammer handle broke!

He's called — walks in — a poker in his hand,</br>A splendid set of china graced the tray;</br>Rich sweetmeats ranged around the phalanx stand,</br>The ladies sit in smiles, and garments gay.</br>Tom stretched his arm, and waved his iron wand,</br>The whole a mass of glittering ruin lay!</br>Then, to the ladies, made a blacksmith's bow,</br>And with complacent smile, said, "Drink tea now, Kate Gow!"

Some women would have screamed, and wept, and fainted,</br>Perhaps have scolded, and increased the strife;</br>But Kate, though she the shame and loss resented,</br>Appeared serene, — a meek submissive wife;</br>And with a smile, that shewed a heart contented,</br>Went calmly to the kitchen — seized a knife—</br>Passed to the smithy, where (as histories tell us)</br>Her angry Vulcan stood, and puffed his ponderous bellows.

Tom turned his head, though he was glad to find</br>That she was come, the quarrel to compound;</br>Kate forced a smile, then softly stole behind,</br>And coolly ripped the roaring bellows round:</br>Tom pulled and tugged, but still there came no wind—</br>Their breath had issued at the yawning wound!</br>With calm composure Kate before him stood,</br>And meekly smiling, said, "Now, puff and blow, Tom Hood!"

The rumbling bellows having breathed their last,</br>Kate, chuckling, like a statue saw him stand;</br>And while he looked like one bewitched, aghast,</br>Advanced, and smiling, pressed his horny hand.</br>"Now, kiss and friends — we'll both forget the past;"</br>She said, — "I love you — honour your command;</br>But mind, my dear, — I'm not a fool — a flat!</br>For wrong by day or night, I'll give you Tit for Tat!"</br>
